title-group.article-title: Experimental and numerical analysis of the boundary layer on a vertical plate at low temperature differences

contrib-group.aff: Institute of Construction and Architecture, Slovak Academy of Sciences, Bratislava, Slovakia

author-notes.corresp: Milan Držík, Institute of Construction and Architecture, Slovak Academy of Sciences, Dúbravská cesta 9, 845 03 Bratislava 45, Slovakia. Email: drzik@ilc.sk

abstract.p: The problem of heat convection from surface to air at very low temperature differences has been solved by experimental/numerical approach. The laser-based probing technique of laser beam deviation detection was developed for the measurement of air refractive index gradients. The data obtained were processed by interactive coupling with numerical modelling tools. As it was approved, the key properties of the boundary layer such as temperature and temperature gradient profiles can be analysed in detail and the impact of various factors can be studied. The numerical simulation and the experimental data comparison had shown good coincidence; nevertheless, at a temperature difference of only few degrees, the influence of ambient air movement has to be considered in simulation process. The presented boundary layer analysis can be successfully applied at specific conditions of building physics with the low temperature differences.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The heat transfer between a solid wall and an air is defined by the temperature difference and the convective heat–transfer coefficients. Heat-transfer coefficient is related to the ambient air parameters, and it is influenced considerably also by convection conditions. In principle, the coefficient can be determined numerically by means of the Kirchhoff law, flow equation and continuity equation. Nevertheless, with regard to potential uncertainty of boundary conditions as well as thermophysical parameters, experimental measurement of the boundary layer is desirable.

Experimentally, information can be obtained about the temperature field through the observation of refractive index changes by non-invasive optical techniques. Several optical methods can be applied for such a measurement, particularly interferometric principles. Not only holographic interferometry (Ambrosini et al., 2001; Mayinger and Feldmann, 2001) and conventional interferometry (Hauf and Grigull, 1970; Zálešák and Kašpar, 1982) but also electronic speckle pattern interferometry (Fomin, 1989) and even speckle pattern shearing interferometry (Shakher and Nirala, 1994) were often used. Besides this, shadow visualization and schlieren method (Vasiljev, 1968) with intensity distribution mapping by photoelectric scanning can be realized.

Fringes of isotherms in the vicinity of solid surface are retrieved by using of the interference techniques. Nevertheless, to obtain temperature gradients necessary for convective heat-transfer coefficient determination, a numerical differentiation is needed of the discrete points of interference fringes. Inherent inaccuracy of the numerical differentiation of discrete experimental data may be considered as a drawback, particularly when small temperature difference between the wall and the ambient air has to be evaluated. This numerical treatment can be avoided in a method of position-sensitive detection of a laser beam deviation induced by refractive index gradients of the medium. Such an approach gives straightforward information about the temperature gradients field. In the proposed technique, the laser beam is passing through the boundary layer along the measured wall. As the beam deflection is directly proportional to the gradient of ambient air refractive index, the information about gradients distribution is retrieved by point-by-point scanning across the layer.

In addition to experimental observation, evolution of temperature and velocity boundary layer was simulated using computational fluid dynamics (CFD). Both the measured and numerically simulated temperature profiles were compared with that of known analytical solutions of free convection near the vertical heated plate. Moreover, some specific problems of numerical solutions applicability were discussed.

sec.title: Laminar free convection on a vertical surface
sec.p: The free convection near the vertical heated plate with constant surface temperature causes characteristic transversal temperature distribution in the boundary layer. It can be illustrated by interference pattern in Figure 1 (Ambrosini, 2002), where isotherms are visualized immediately as interference fringes. In the picture, the rise of interference fringes density in the bottom of the heated plate is also visible (Figure 1(a)), which means the higher temperature gradient. This is apparently affected by the missing aerodynamic profile regulating the air flow at the bottom of the heated plate and also by sudden change in conditions at the interface. At this position, approximately uniform distribution is visible. In the middle part – interference fringes – isotherms are drifting apart, boundary layer is extending and temperature gradient close to the surface is gradually decreasing. If the free-flow temperature is constant, convective heat–transfer coefficient decreases with widening of the boundary layer. Near the upper part of the heated plate (Urgela, 1999), isotherms are compressed (Figure 1(b)), temperature gradients grow and convective heat–transfer coefficient values rise again. In this region, boundary layer is detached by turbulent ambient air.

sec.p: Suppose that the wall surface has a temperature Tsi, and the ambient air has a temperature T. The air temperature is isothermal with the exception of the boundary layer thickness near the wall surface. The boundary layer is formed in the interface of two different phases, on the fluid side. The air flow in the layer is regarded as laminar. As in the laminar flow the streamlines do not cross each other, the fluid elements move in parallel with the velocity v and the heat through boundary layer is transported perpendicularly by convection.

sec.title: Experimental setup
sec.p: For the purpose of experimental boundary layer analysis, the vertical flat plates consisting of two symmetrically heated parts were fabricated. Two materials with different thermal conductivity were used. First, the plate consisting of two gypsum boards with the embedded heating foil inside was measured. The dimensions of the plate were 0.52 × 0.50 × 0.02 m. Subsequently, the gypsum boards were replaced by the polished aluminium plates with dimensions of 0.5 × 0.5 × 0.09 m and with foil heating input of 197 W/m2.

For gypsum plate with relatively low thermal conductivity (0.15 W/m.K), some heterogeneity of the surface temperature field was expected. Therefore, the perimeter of the plate was thermally insulated with the 3-mm thick expanded polystyrene belt and aluminium foil. This gypsum plate was used in the experiments with higher surface-ambient temperature differences.

On the other hand, the polished aluminium plate has a significantly higher thermal conductivity (200 W/m.K), providing a higher homogeneity of surface temperature field. Low infrared (IR) emissivity of about 0.04 reduced the radiative heat exchange. Such a plate was used in the experiments with low surface to ambient temperature differences.

Configuration of the measurement equipment is shown in Figure 2. The measurement assembly consists of a laser diode, 10 mW/650 nm fixed in an adjustable holder and a double-cell photodiode detector as the primary elements of the measuring setup. The air and surface temperatures were detected by thermocouples. In addition, the real temperature distribution of the gypsum plate surface was displayed by IR camera NEC TH7102MX. The thermocouple sensitivity was 0.1°C.

Under the calm air conditions with the absence of temperature gradient and strong air speed, the laser beam illuminates both the halves of the double-cell photodiode detector equally. Whenever the air temperature gradient occurs, the air density decreases and the laser beam deviates from a straight line. The double-cell photodiode captures the difference between the two light-detecting halves (Figure 2(a) and (b)). The difference signal is proportional to the deviation of the beam from a straight line (Figure 2(b)) and is read on a voltmeter and displayed on the oscilloscope screen. The oscilloscope reveals potential signal distortion, which is due to undesirable turbulence of the ambient air in the position of the probing laser beam. In order to suppress this uncertainty, the linear averaging of the number of time traces has been carried out. Signal to digital voltmeter was filtered as well by low-pass filter. The values were read by several seconds downloading intervals.

Each measurement was performed by the couple of laser diode–photodiode detector at a given position alongside the heated plate. The plate was moved step-by-step through the use of its mounting on a translation stage, while the laser beam position remained fixed. The values of the gradient signals were read after the ambient air tranquillization.

The adjustment of the initial state dn/dy = 0 was made at the position of the laser beam trace far enough from the plate surface. Using the micro-translation stage the measuring double photodiode detector was being displaced step by step perpendicularly to the laser beam trace. Thus, the calibration of the dependence between the value of the electrical signal (mV) and the simulated deviation of the laser beam trace (µm) was obtained. The calibration diagram has shown good linearity throughout the whole range of measurement from 0 to 300 µm.

The measurement of temperature/refractive index gradients inside boundary layer was recorded within the distances from y = 2 to 26 mm. The results smaller than 2 mm from the surface are not reliable due to the finite laser beam diameter (about 1.5 mm). The evaluation process assumes the constant temperature gradient along the heated plate. In reality, there was difficulty in keeping the homogeneous distribution of the surface temperature across the whole gypsum plate area (Figure 3(a)). Therefore, we have proposed a correction of the temperature value along the heated plate as a weighted value.

sec.title: Numerical modelling
sec.p: Formation of the boundary layer has been simulated using the CFD simulation tool (OpenFOAM User and Programmers Guide, 2008). OpenFOAM operates in a three-dimensional Cartesian coordinate system. Transient icoFoam solver implemented in the software allows incompressible laminar flow cases to be solved. Nevertheless, this solver does not include an energy equation. Modification of icoFoam by adding mass force to the momentum equation and including the temperature equation as a passive scalar according to Sosnowski and Pozorski (2009) have to be done.
The problem is governed by transient, three-dimensional equations of continuity, momentum and energy in the form of the following equations

where Uf is the velocity of fluid (m/s), µ is the dynamic viscosity (Pa-s), ρf is the fluid density (kg/m3), β is the volumetric expansion coefficient (1/K), Tf is the fluid temperature (K), T0 is the reference temperature (K), g is the gravitational constant (m/s2), p is the pressure (Pa), kf is the thermal conductivity of the fluid (W/m·K) and c is the specific heat capacity (J/kg·K).

The Boussinesq approximation was used to account for the natural convection effects. Such an approximation assumes that the thermal properties of fluid do not affect greatly its density except for the buoyancy term.

The model consists of the zone with one heated wall and two openings for the air inlet and outlet (Figure 4). Pre-processing tool blockMesh has been used to create structural grid, and 1-mm control volume thickness was used in the near to wall region. It means 1.2 million volumetric elements were generated. The problem requires steady-state solution; consequently, the simulation proceeded until steady state was achieved.

sec.p: As the ambient air flow cannot be neglected generally, the calculations were carried out with ambient air velocity 0.1 m/s, 0.2 m/s and 0.3 m/s. It should be noted that the calculation with different air flow velocities was not intended to describe the actual air convection in the room that was not measured experimentally. Therefore, the simulation of the influence of ambient flow was aimed only to analyse basic tendencies of the near-surface flow on the temperature gradients as well as the temperature behaviour across the boundary layer.

In Figure 5, the experimentally determined values of the temperature gradients are presented together with their fitted curves of the discrete values obtained by using equation (19). In the experimentally determined values, error bars are also drawn. These were obtained as a standard deviation σ by recording time-dependent fluctuations of the measured detector signal. The time traces of the signal recorded during such stationary measurement conditions were numerically processed as a stationary time function for value of standard deviation. As it was recognized, the dominant error in the experimental determination of temperature gradients had origin in the near-wall air turbulence, which acted as a main source of signal fluctuation. Each of the experimental value was registered as detector signal averaged throughout 10 s of the measurement time.
Besides this, in Figure 5, the curves of numerical simulations computed by using CFD according to OpenFOAM tool are drawn too.

As seen in Figure 5, the temperature gradients observed at higher temperature difference near gypsum plate show good coincidence with the results computed by CFD. When the temperature difference is small, the experimental values become noticeably different.

Likewise for temperature gradients, the discrepancies between the measured temperature profiles and the profiles computed by CFD modelling and also by using analytical expressions appear substantial for higher temperature contrast (see Figure 6). In Figure 6, dimensionless temperature profiles based on analytical solution and CFD are drawn, taking into account similarity solution to the problem obtained by Ostrach (1953) and Bejan (1984), where the similarity parameters according to equations (22), (23) and (24) were used. Both the experimental and numerical results are compared with the analytical solutions proposed by Ostrach (1953) – left-hand side figures – and also by Bejan (1984) – right-hand side figures. As it can be seen, the experimental values observed at higher contrast between wall and ambient air temperatures coincide well in the region of the analytical/numerical solutions. At the same time, the discrepancy between the values of small temperature differences is highlighted. It implies that at higher temperature difference conditions, the influence of natural air flow convection has to be more intensive. It has to be noticed that at the free laboratory conditions, the influence of forced convection due to air movement cannot be completely eliminated.

caption.p: Dimensionless temperature profiles calculated from the temperature gradients by integration according to equation (10) and their comparison with CFD simulations/analytical solutions. Left-hand side: Ostrach (1953) approach and right-hand side: Bejan (1984).

sec.p: Since forced convection of the surrounding air in the CFD model can be neglected, the results of the CFD and analytical solutions are nearly identical. Accordingly, CFD model can be successfully implemented for appropriate adjusting of the boundary conditions of analytical solution.

Comparing both the analytical solutions with CFD results of natural convection near vertical heated plate, Bejan’s (1984) solution seems to be slightly closer to the CFD solution, particularly in the range of η = 0–1.5. Despite the small differences, both the analytical solutions for air (Pr 0.72) are similar.

As the effect of the forced convection seems to be important, in a next step, we have tried to analyse ambient air velocity effect as one of the boundary conditions. The velocities typical for indoor air movement were considered at a vertical direction of the flow v = 0.1, 0.2 and 0.3 m/s. As it is shown in the left-hand side of Figure 7, in the case of air velocity v = 0.3 m/s, the difference of the CFD-modelled temperature gradient value at ΔT = 1.5 K increases by 90 K/m, while at ΔT = 12.2 K, this value increases up to 150 K/m. The difference is more significant in percentage of absolute value at small temperature differences. For example, in the simulated value of ΔT = 1.5 K, this difference is about 70%, while at ΔT = 12.2K, the difference is only about 12%.

sec.p: In addition to the transversal temperature profiles across the boundary layer, vertical profiles of convective heat–transfer coefficient near vertical heated plate was calculated by using CFD simulation. Comparison of the simulation results and measured values is shown in Figure 8. As the empirical formulations give averaged values for the whole surface area, the experimental values cannot be confronted with them immediately due to their local nature. For this purpose, vertical profiles of hc were recalculated into averaged values by using numerical integration and were normalized by the plate height. As it was recognized, dominant impact of the ambient air speed on the local values of convective heat–transfer coefficient was obtained mainly near the bottom part of vertical heated plate. Thus, the ambient air flow cannot be neglected, as it seems during the experiment the average indoor air velocity was around 0.2 m/s.

caption.p: Illustration of the calculated convective heat–transfer coefficients along the vertical direction and the values of experimentally obtained coefficients hc.

sec.p: The heat-transfer coefficient is a key parameter describing conditions of the heat energy exchange between the wall and the surrounding air. Averaged values of hc as a function of temperature difference for various air flow velocities are plotted in Figure 9. In this figure, there are also curves drawn by means of empirical formulae, which describe convective heat transfer near vertical heated surface by several authors. The character of the dependencies conforms with the empirical dependencies, and moreover, the quantitative values cover the region calculated by empirical expressions.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In the field of building physics, there is a common problem of reliable near-wall boundary layer analysis at very low temperature contrast of wall versus ambient air is often the case. One opportunity is a development of more sensitive and reliable measurement method. Such an experimental support can be regarded also as a base for the evaluation of variety of numerical modelling tools. For this reason, an optical non-invasive method that does not influence the conditions in the boundary layer has been developed. The method is based on position-sensitive detection of a laser beam deviation induced by refractive index gradients inside boundary layer. Regarding the photoelectric sensing, the detection can be very sensitive. Moreover, such a probing technique gives straightforward information about the temperature gradients field important from the point of view of heat transfer information gathering. Robustness and simple scheme realization make possible the application of the boundary layer measurement even in building practice conditions to measure near-wall temperature gradients.

In order to analyse information obtained, the mutual interaction of the experimental data as well as data obtained by numerical and analytical tools has been applied. To evaluate the data, the temperature gradient dependences were plotted. As it was approved, at higher temperature difference conditions, better coincidence with the data of CFD modelling has been observed, and on the contrary, at smaller temperature differences, the experimental values disagree noticeably. Besides this, influence of even small ambient air velocity on the convective heat-transfer coefficient at low temperature contrast wall surface versus ambient air has been shown to be significant.
In addition, applicability of the known empirical expressions for the convective heat-transfer coefficient has been evaluated.

The proposed approach of experimental/numerical analysis of the boundary layer has shown its usefulness and effectiveness. The boundary layer can be studied even at very low temperature contrast of only a few degrees, common for building physics conditions.
